floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Heavy rain is forecast to affect London throughout Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt or Tottenham areas, there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and gardens is possible from Saturday morning. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

We expect the band of rain to move out of the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with strong winds. 

The first forecast high water is 22:00 on 04/08/23 with a level of 6.46 mAOD and a Force 4 North Westerly wind. 
The second forecast high water is 10:15 on 05/08/23 with a level of 6.31 mAOD and a Force 7 South Westerly wind. 

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Due to increasing wind strength, there is a risk of property flooding so Flood Warnings may be issued for tomorrow mornings tide.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will update this message as necessary.

This message will be updated by 15:00 on Saturday, 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.67mAOD at 06:15 on 05/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 40 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:30 on 05/08/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We may see further rainfall over the next few days and this Flood Alert will be re-issued if needed.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:00 on 05/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 Westerly winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. The total forecast tide is 5.24 metres Chart Datum (2.50 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour, similar to that seen on Wednesday 02/08/2023. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. After this tide‚ the weather becomes more settled‚ with smaller waves and lighter winds. Sunday's early morning tide is predicted to be 20cm lower and tide levels will fall towards neaps over the coming week. Flood risk will reduce and no further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/08/2023.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:15 on 05/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.21 metres Chart Datum (3.16 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. From Sunday 06/08/2023‚ the weather becomes more settled‚ with smaller waves and lighter winds. Sunday's early morning tide is predicted to be 20cm lower and tide levels will fall towards neaps over the coming week. Flood risk will reduce and no further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/08/2023.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Coastal conditions have now passed. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Coastal conditions should ease for the 04/08/2023 high tide at 21:45 hours. We will continue to monitor tide levels into the weekend and will reissue flood alerts if necessary.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast for the next couple of days is for more unsettled weather which could affect tide heights over the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 02:45am and 04:45am tomorrow morning, Saturday 5th August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46mAODN at 03:45am, Saturday 5th August, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 2, south-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 11:00am on Saturday 5th August.

Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast for the next couple of days is for more unsettled weather which could affect tide heights over the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible today (04/08/2023). Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes Levels are rising steadily and further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday (05/08/2024) or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 10:30 PM on 04/08/2023 with a level of 7.50 mAODN with westerly force 3 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:45 AM on 05/08/2023 with a level of 7.37 mAODN with westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

After this tide‚ and the passing of Storm Antoni the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We are closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton and we will continue to monitor levels closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 9pm and 10pm this evening, 04/08/23. Flooding of roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.5m Friday evening and 7.3 to 7.4m Saturday morning.  Newport 7.1m to 7.2m Friday evening and 6.8 to 7.1 m Saturday morning, 05/08/23
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on 05/08/23, or as the situation changes.

The high tide is expected to be higher than usual at the Mersey Estuary at Warrington as a result of high spring tides.  Consequently, flooding of low lying land is possible tomorrow morning, 05/08/23, peaking at 2.45 am at the following places: 

Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 6.3 meters,

Eastford Road will peak at 6.45 meters, 

Arpley Bridge will peak at 6.5 meters.

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated when the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be higher than normal overnight 04/08/2023 to 05/08/2023. After tonight the forecast tide levels decrease and we do not anticipate issuing alerts after tomorrow. No property flooding is expected.
The highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 02:15 AM tomorrow morning. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Forecast tide level is 5.25m Above Ordnance Datum.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible at high spring tides Friday evening 04/08/23 with high water at Ilfracombe 21:07. On Saturday morning 05/08/23, Storm Antoni is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.  High water at Ilfracombe at 09:30. Times of high water will vary along the coast

Force 7 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 2.8m are forecast, which could result in wave overtopping of sea defences and localised flooding in exposed coastal locations. Expect tides to be up to 0.28m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. This message will be updated by noon on 05/08/23 or as the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Friday at 21:07 is 5.04 mAOD, this is 0.04 metres above astronomical tide level. The forecast high tide level on Saturday at 09:30 is 4.85 mAOD, this is 0.28 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Silk Stream and the Deans, Edgware, Dollis, Mutton and Wealdstone Brooks
items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Heavy rain is forecast to affect London throughout Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware or Stanmore areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from Saturday morning. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to move out of the area on Saturday evening. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We continue to deploy resources and are working closely with emergency services, the local authority and partners in the Tokyngton area on the Wembley Brook.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

We have issued a Flood Alert. Heavy rain is forecast to affect London throughout Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Hatch End, Pinner, Ruislip, Ickenham, Hillingdon, or Uxbridge areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from Saturday morning. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

We expect the band of rain to move out of the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Yeading Brooks in London Boroughs of Harrow and Hillingdon

floodArea.riverOrSea: Yeading Brook West, Yeading Brook East

items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Heavy rain is forecast to affect London throughout Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Harrow or Hillingdon areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from Saturday morning. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

We expect the band of rain to move out of the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

As a result of spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest tomorrow morning at 10:45 AM on 05/08/2023.

Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.
The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.37 mAODN, which is 0.30 m above tide tables, with westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

The risk of flooding from Storm Antoni will reduce after this high tide. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels are rising on the lower River Derwent due to rainfall during the week. Areas most at risk of flooding overnight include local roads and low-lying land around Elvington. Levels are rising and other areas including Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle and Wilberfoss may be at risk tomorrow due to further rainfall forecast on Saturday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.
